newsitem.title: USA: DSP agrees to acquire Proxim; sparking DSP stock drop.
newsitem.headline: DSP agrees to acquire Proxim; sparking DSP stock drop.

text.p: DSP Communications Inc. said Tuesday it agreed to acquire wireless networking product maker Proxim Inc. in a stock deal originally valued at about $400 million, sparking a steep drop in DSP's shares.

DSP stock tumbled $17.125 to $35.25 on Nasdaq amid concerns it may have paid too much, while Proxim's shares rose $2.80 to $21.50. Based on DSP's closing stock price of $52.375 on Monday the deal would be valued at $400 million, but the overall value fluctuates with the stock price.
Under terms of the deal, Proxim shareholders will get 0.70 DSP common share for each Proxim share.

Proxim, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes high performance wireless data networking products, and Cupertino, Calif.-based DSP develops and markets chip sets and systems for the wireless personal communications market.
DSP officials said they were confident the merger would not dilute earnings.

"Analysts estimate that it will be 5 percent dilutive" in 1997, said DSP Chief Executive Nathan Hod at an industry conference in Monterey, Calif. "Knowing what analysts don't know about DSP, I believe this deal will not be dilutive," he said.

The companies said the merger would extend DSP's strength in both wireless voice and data communications. The merger comes a year after DSP acquired CTP Systems Ltd., a leader in wireless telephone systems.
Several analysts called the sell-off an overreaction.

"This is a great story from a long-term perspective," said Robert Kaimowitz, analyst with Unterberg Harris. "I believe it could be marginally dilutive in 1997, but could easily be accretive by 1998 and 1999," he said.
DSP officials said they expected to quickly see benefits from the merger.

"DSP's Israeli subsidiaries have a very beneficial tax situation and we believe that ... some of Proxim's activities will be able to base out of Israel and by doing that we'll be able to get a very significant positive bottom line effect for Proxim," Gerald Dogon, DSP chief financial officer, said on a conference call after the news was announced.
"That's something we'll be working on in the short term, and we believe that already in 1997 it will start to have positive effects on Proxim," he said.
DSP Chairman Davidi Gilo said the deal allowed for an adjustment based on each company's fourth quarter results, which would allow a change in the exchange ratio.
